commentBody: This was so cute!!!!! The final grid spanner was very fun. Probably closer to a Monday than a Tuesday in difficulty but a fun time nonetheless.
Looooved it!
Made me laugh! Great fun.
Waow, based!

66A‚Ä¶ it brought a smile to my face. I enjoy the occasional absurd answer, similar to that puzzle from last year that was full of T‚Äôs.

Fun ride. Thanks for contributing.
Laughed when I figured out 66a. Cute and fun one today!
Thought I was looooosing my mind at first with oooooolll the ooooooos. Interesting puzzle enjoyable
People loved this?  Really?  Meh.  The whole puzzle created to create one single line oddity?
Somebody filed a Monday puzzle in the wrong place.
Wow. Just wow.
Cute! Always look forward to Erik Agard puzzles.

I would have to agree with Sam's assessment of the abbreviation rule.

An abbreviation marker is necessary only when an abbreviation is not the most common iteration of the thing in question.  Here, KOS is easily recognized alongside the full word "knockouts"; in fact, it's often spelled "kayos".  Also, and more importantly, if the abbreviation is read out as written, the abbr. marker isn't needed.  That doesn't mean that they couldn't be provided anyway, but the only time they are actually required is when they're not pronounced as they are abbreviated (e.g. BDRM), and they are not usually used as the common version of the item in question.

So, some of the recent answers that have taken the abbr. marker are BDRM, ANON(ymous), PSI for tire inflation, AMT (amount), MASC(uline), ELEC(tric), MTN for mountain, etc.  But you'll also see UAE, a common shortening akin to USA or UK, and MASS, which is one of the few states whose abbreviation is read as a word (as if it were what grams measure).  So it's up to the discretion of the editor to include the marker in the latter case.
Does anybody really say "wow" like that? I thought 66A was over-indulge over-indulgent, and being overindulgence-prone myself, I feel qualified to say so.
I always enjoy Erik‚Äôs puzzles; he always seems to bring something special to them. This one was no exception.

A discovery I just made about viewing the comments and the column at the same time on my desktop PC, and being able to scroll either one up and down independently:

I had previously noted that at some point each day, the setup went from only being able to scroll the comments, while the column remained stationary unless you closed out of the comments.

Recently, I realized that the first time you open the comments, you have that setup.  But all you need to do is refresh the page, and you have the two scroll bars, and you can scroll either one.  Even if it's the first few minutes the comments are up.

Very convenient to be able to refer back to any part of the column without having to close the comments first.
This one made me smile :) Liked it a lot.

A story about accents, brought to you by 66A:

A coworker with a pretty strong Boston accent was claiming he could usually tell where people were from.
Me: ‚Äúwell I don‚Äôt have an accent‚Äù
Him: ‚Äúoh yes you do‚Äù
Me: ‚ÄúNoooooooooo I don‚Äôt‚Äù

Can you hear it? Where do you think I grew up?
Ok, I'm lost. Could someone explain what a HEAD DANCER has to do with powwows?

Absolutely hilarious puzzle.  First one to make me laugh out loud in a long time. Much appreciated, Erik!

‚ÄúWhyyyyyyyyyy?  My only son!‚Äù
What did I just solve?! LOL

Always like to see an Eric Agard puzzle (even on a Saturday). There's always something a little different or unusual that gives exposure to new ideas or facts that I normally would not encounter, and I appreciate the chance to learn, even at my age.

Not much trouble with today's puzzle, although I guessed at something I shouldn't have and didn't cross-check until I got the "RUH-ROH!" message at the end. Fortunately, it didn't take long to find and fix.

Thanks, Erik!

Nice puzzle and fill with some clueing that I haven't seen before.

The string of O's was neat.

But proper nouns shouldn't intersect. (MAN and AHED. 

7.5/10
Lolol
Cute

So many fun word pairings, especially NONO and OKOK and HEADDANCE crossing Cherokee Nation. Also noticed AMPSUP and REV.
A fun and smooth solve - more Erik Agard puzzles, please!
Very fun! Thanks Erik Agard!
Wooooooooooooow.
Apropos of nothing, I really wish the crossy was playable in my browser's dark mode.

I have never heard of Church Rock uranium spill until tonight. Thank you for enlightening me. 
Now that's wooooooooooooow.

Tied my PW for a Tuesday Xword because I jumped to the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù answer for 17A:  IDONTBELIEVEYOU.  Who says ICANTBELIEVEYOU upon being incredulous about something someone else has said?  (One might say ICANTBELIEVEIT.)  So there!

Not feeling it tonight.  Got outside for some fresh air in the minus temps.  Re-hit a personal best from
my 20‚Äôs and 30‚Äôs only to get my tuchus handed to me on a Tuesday puzzle.  

Just keep moving.

Did anyone else feel a little twinge of delight after seeing four 0s in a row and realizing what this puzzle was accomplishing?

Bravo!
A very fun puzzle!  Lots of fun crosses.  One cheat, as I didn't know the black/white bird.  I'll remember that one in the future.

"Someone just installed an apiary at the topiary!"
"I can't bee-leaf yew."

(Hive been known to branch out with these.)

Crossword Revolution Day 28:  REST





Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢

An ideal opportunity, given that one of his favorite responses in these annals is "SRSLY" to call for the Mayor of this shire, Mr. Barry Ancona to serve for another term, at least, whereas the mayor of Mr. Ancona's own shire will not be so lucky (Lord willing). All hail Barry Ancona for his long service to his wordplaying constituents. Seriously!

I'm of mixed feelings about this puzzle, and not least because [Identity thieves' targets for short] precisely describes the crew currently infesting Treasury and now coming after our SSNS. No, it wasn't the triggered mourning for my lost future means of support, although that weighs heavily on me, it was the lacklustre cluing of the top tiers (and some areas beneath) which so jarred with the brilliance of the theme set. Examples? [Got 100% on]--ACED. I see the name Agar I expect better, "mustered" level cluing throughout. Instead it's [____Major (bear constellation)] -- SRSLY?

But on the plus side, great to see two black and white sea creatures, the swans and the orca (which also had a pedestrian clue), and a third, Nessie, who changes color with each sighting. I'd hazard she's puce. 

Loved Head Dancer. Made me cringe, remembering once in my young adulthood suggesting a pow-wow to a woman who turned out to be part-Seneca and who took deep offense, and that's the last time I ever used that expression, even though I can't remember what exactly I was proposing, but I was likely hoping for some canoodling. Seriously.
Wow, this one really went through all the classics, huh? ORCA, I DO, SPA, EDEN, INON, ACT...and that's just in the top half!

Was anyone else reminded of...

So when you're happy (Hurray!) or sad (Aw!)
Or frightened (Eeeeeek!) or mad (Rats!)
Or excited (Wooooooooooooow!) or glad (Hey!)
An interjection starts a sentence right.

Like most others, I delighted in the very un-serious line of Os. At first I thought something was amiss, but once I caught on I cheerfully filled in the rest of the string without even reading the Down clues. 

Sometimes a little bit of whimsy is all you need to really bring a puzzle to life.
oh yeah, this puzzle rules

Thank you, Erik! I CANTBELIEVEYOU! THEAUDACITY of you giving us WOOOOOOOOW! That‚Äôs why I love seeing an Erik Agard puzzle ‚Äîit‚Äôs always something delightful to discover.  

Also, it‚Äôs funny that we recently had ‚Äúdamask‚Äù as the answer for a cloth named after a Levant country‚Äôs capital. Here it is again, as Damascus, SYRIA‚Äôs capital.

What a clever puzzle! I thoroughly enjoyed it. 65A was impressive all alone in making the answer fit, but the piece de resistance was Dijon-mustered "yes"? Kudos to you!
Sam is about to hear the sirens of The Natick Police. üöì
I could have done an alphabet run for the middle square L of the Mini, but it was much quicker just to google "alvin ai."

I confidently entered ARE YOU KIDDING ME for 17A, but alas it wasn‚Äôt to be when I attempted the downs. But then I entered the phrase once more at 66A thinking my brilliance was just a little too early ü§£ Imaging my surprise as that entry turned into WOOOOOOOOOOOOOW. I still like my answer and it perfectly fit the theme. Thank you, Erik, for keeping me on my toes‚Ä¶seriously ü§®
So much fun!

Great puzzle, and I loved the theme, but I must register a complaint for 26D. After just celebrating 50 years of SNL, I wish the term ‚Äúsketch‚Äù was more widely used and understood to describe short comedy scenes, rather than the more common term (but less right, to my ear), SKITS.

Solving this puzzle was like going to another place. Unexpected fills (AREACODE) a shocking answer (CHURCHROCK) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Church_Rock_uranium_mill_spill and HEADDANCER‚Äîall were recognition of the nation within our nation, the Navajo. The puzzle wasn't difficult (quickly solved) but the welcome distraction of different path (mostly clean as a whistle‚Äîa couple of IDOs and ONITs, which I didn't mind) was deeply appreciated. I am home almost all the time now, and I can't seem to stop watching the news and obsessing about the sinister path our country is on. Thank you, Erik.
Did no one pick up on the pun "Dijon -mustered (mustard) assent?
Oh, I got it!
I‚Äôm a newbie in this and this is my first time solving a Tuesday puzzle without help!! I cried
When I first saw the row of O's, I was convinced I did something wrong until I got to the W! That was fun!
Hilarious and satisfying. Thanks, Erik.

Since when do I get my mind blown so many times on a Tuesday? First there's 66A. I was suspicious that something funny was up after about six Os. Brilliant!Then the two links in Sam's column about what is a word. Pow, pow! Then dutchiris' link to Church Rock. Holy cow! I worked in environmental remediation, including many Superfund sites, and I'd never heard of Church Rock. No wonder the Navajo Nation resists uranium mines. 

Well-funded, independent state and federal environmental protection agencies are vital to our well-being. I believe in using our natural resources, but never trust industry to police itself. Never. When push comes to shove, they will always chose the bottom line over public health.
I never comment on here but this puzzle was just awesome.

My initial thought was ‚Äòwhat a fun puzzle‚Äô, slightly thrown by having H instead of W at the start of 66A.

Then I read the link that @DutchChris posted re CHURCH ROCK. Having read that I now understand why I hadn‚Äôt come across it before. I don‚Äôt know whether to cry or scream. The inhumanity is beyond my comprehension.

The prolific Eric Agard always offers teaching moments and humor.  I loved THE AUDACITY of including 66 A.  

When I saw how many comments there were so early this morning, I assumed there would be a lot of complaints, but was happy to see that many enjoyed this as much as I did.

Another tough Tuesday. This one took me 50% longer than average. 

I kept tiptoeing around the Kennewick area, but like Sam I broke it open with MAN.

Once I accepted, there was gonna be a bazillion letter Os in a row, I kind of liked it.  Wow, indeed.

WOOOOOOW enjoyed that. i think i was on the same wavelength as mr. asgard today - the solve was incredibly smooth for me (except i had HOOOW instead of WOOOW..). loved DOG-EARED and WHO DOES THAT? fun!

Nice Tuesday challenge. I was appropriately puzzled by 66 across for a good long time until I finally had enough down crosses for it to dawn on me. Just made for a nice 'aha' moment. 

One answer history search today was for answers with long strings of O's. Been done quite a few times. One example was a fifteen letter: IOOOOOOOOOOOOOO: With the clue: "Ten million squared."  And another 15 letter example: 
"Really long celebratory cry." 
GOOOOOOOOOOOOAL

And there were more. But then stumbled across an interesting puzzle from one of my favorite constructors. I'll put that in a reply. 

....

With just _______________OOW in the grid it was unbelievably audacious to add in all the rest in one go, but it paid off!
Great one, thanks Erik!
This theme is excellent!! WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOW made me smile. Great Tuesday, full of creative and enjoyable cluing.

I fair flew through this one, quite a few familiar friends (CDS, DAB, UAE) and fortunately got the proper names with the crossers, except 1A - I looked up Astro but got a Korean band?
I also had to get the 'seriously' clues mostly with the crossers! I don't  really use those phrases. 
The Scots equivalent might be: 
"Aye, right"
"That's nae real"
Or even
"You think I cam up the (river) Clyde oan a bicycle?"

66A- a word I have used on occasion, usually in response to something someone has said that is rude, uncalled for, or is an exceptional burn. Spoken softly, with many inflections in the "O" sound.

This was a delightfully fun puzzle to solve, my favorite clue being the punny 67D-
[Dijon-mustered "yes"?] OUI

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I‚Äôve inexplicably taken in the past eight years, it is my duty to inform you that this puzzle, despite the stretched ‚Äúwow‚Äù, does not have an unusually high number of double letters, where unusual is 20 or more.  (That ‚Äúwow‚Äù answer counts as six.)  The last unusually-high puzzle occurred 1/31/24. 

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.
Paxil is a little dated for 68-Down. Nowadays, Prozac is standard of care
A fun puzzle. Is a crisis a catastrophe??

We Non-US folks sometimes struggle with americanisms, especially when it comes to sports-related clues. Sometimes it even goes over my head that a clue asks about an American sports. Or what sport. 

So it is very refreshing to have one with no such American trivia and barely any proper nouns. Thanks, Mr Agard, this was a very enjoyable solve!
Thanks for starting my day with a big smile!
Thank you Erik for 29D. More like this, please. Many more.

I loved the meta ‚Äì Looking at WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOW, then reading over the other three theme answers and seeing that they are the perfect reaction.

What also gave me a big smile was [Dijon-mustered ‚Äúyes‚Äù?] for OUI, mostly because of the scintillating wordplay, but also because this is an answer that has appeared in the major crossword outlets more than 400 times, but never clued like this. ‚ÄòTis a special brain to come up with a clue like that.

Regarding the o-train, two questions come to mind:
‚Ä¢	How many O‚Äôs did you have filled in when it hit you that it was going to a full string?
‚Ä¢	When it did hit you, what was your reaction?

(My answers: Five and a huge ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù)

Loveliness along the way with BUOY, PITHY, THE AUDACITY, and WHO DOES THAT, plus a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap in STOPS.  As for the junk-free answer set, that comes standard in an Agard.

A puzzle with a kapow is rare and wonderful, and thank you for this one, Erik!

and have stellar hair!

Like yesterday's, I felt this was harder than normal for its day, and yet I completed in less time than normal for a Tuesday. Strange.

I found this quite challenging for a Tuesday‚Ä¶finished around half a minute above my average for the day. Still, given our new era, I appreciated being able to focus on something other than cruelty and the tragic results of it, so, thank you.
I seriously wanted AREYOUKIDDINGME but will settLe for W...W. Fun puzzle!

As a relatively recent daily puzzler, today was the first time I had the joy of opening up the puzzle and recognizing the constructor name from a previous puzzle that I loved. I knew we‚Äôd be in for a treat. 

Like many others here, I laughed out loud when I put together 66A. And I appreciate the discerning use of just a few good proper nouns. 

Thanks Mr. Agard! Looking forward to your next one.

‚ÄúExtends his regards‚Äù?

‚ÄúBit of a stretch‚Äù?

I see what you did there. I love it! Keep them coming.

I will have to look up the CHURCH ROCK 'radioactive accident' because I've never heard of it; ditto DHubby.  Maybe while I was out of the country for a couple of years?  Was it near that Area Fifty-something?

I thought AHED was a bit unfair.  
WHO says Rail Trail?  Anyone?  anyone?  Bueller?

I wonder how much money I've saved over my lifetime by seldom using any make-up of any sort?  (We can't count 7th grade, when just about every girl was excited to be putting on lipstick.  And I did buy a lipstick for our son's wedding.)  But I've never used blush, mascara, eye-liner, pancake, eyebrow pencil...  Lip Balm.  That's it.  Speeds up one's morning.

First, I loved the photo at the beginning of this article, with the caption "Cheetahs never prosper".  Cute:  sounds like a clue... "____ never prosper?"  
Second, wooooooooooooow made me laugh out loud.  Like others, I thought with the first three or four O's I must be wrong.  What a spark of joy when I figured it out!  Thank you!

A nice balance of gimmes and surprising, unusual answers made this a fun Tuesday puzzle,...

but I'm still not sure how I feel about 66-Across.
Much fun! A true Tuesday level puzzle with a kicker at the end. Many thanks!
L'audace, l'audace, toujours l'audace.
66A wowed me.

My comment got emu'd
T'was politically skewed
How rude! I haiku-ed.
Absolutely loved this puzzle. Much Fun. WOW. I love puzzles with a simple straightforward twist and internal joke.

LOVED this, what a great start to my Tuesday. Pleased to see one for the millennials: THE AUDACITY was just right. The top right corner was one of my last empty spots and there was a point where I had __CKNO for 16a... and I was like... "Seriously?!" How's that for a fitting theme!

WOOOOOOOOOOOOOW, I must have been really tired. I had MACES for "duel units," which kind of worked but that would have been quite a duel! Thought I'd finished and checked the whole puzzle (with no joy). Took a 45-minute nap and rechecked. Oh yeah, I don't think photo OMS are a thing. THE AUDACITY! The streak lives on :)

Just a comment not a spoiler.

Oh, and did I mention the rare-in-crosswords 15-letter palindrome?







Et tu emu.
37D:  fourth WHAT after Aug.?  If it was month, it would be Nov.  I'm confused.
Nice to learn that so many people in the Cherokee Nation have cell phones that a second area code was needed.

13 vowels in a row, WHO DOES THAT?!

So close to beating my PB, I thoroughly enjoyed this solve!

The approach of the New York Times crossword puzzle takes when the fill is the name of someone who has done terrible things is to clue that fill innocuously without reference to those terrible things. I‚Äôve objected to it before and I‚Äôm objecting to it again today.

Other than that, Mrs. Lincoln, how was the play? 

Well, I had SHAN for an embarrassingly long time, making this a very long Tuesday solve for me and making me feel very foolish. Glad to have found my error and kept the streak alive. (I‚Äôm now obsessed with my streak and can‚Äôt blow it on a Tuesday!)
I think this was easier than the Monday, but nice puzzle!

PR by a mile ü•≥ I had this solved in two passes (across-down, across-down), and am now wondering, what is everyone's preferred solving method? Quadrants, bottom to top, straight through as written...?

Really nice to see Erik A. back again, even on a Tuesday.

This puzzle was very admirable, in that the cluing really sparkled, but the puzzle was easy enough for the Tuesday crowd.

Thanks Erik! How about a Friday or Saturday puzzle sometime soon!

Fun puzzle.

Funnier blog photo.

Thank you Erik and Sam
Erik Agard puzzles are the best!!!

I also want to thank @dutchiris for the Church Rock article link. Even though I was living in New Mexico at the time, I was completely UNfamiliar with this event! Granted, as a 14yo I didn‚Äôt watch the evening news, but I did read our local newspaper (Roswell Daily Record). And that following school year, as a 9th grader in the speech and debate club, I was preparing speeches about Love Canal and ‚ÄúSilent Spring‚Äùand other assorted environmental disasters. Surprising to learn only now that this was going on in my proverbial backyard!
Congratulations, what a great achievement :) Soon you'll be solving Saturdays! :)
Can someone please explain 23D?

About a half hour ago, I posted re. one of the entries in today‚Äôs puzzle, which featured a controversial figure. I used a healthy dose of bothsidesism and expressed no personal feelings toward the name, except for surprise at its inclusion. 

Poof, the post is gone. The puzzle entry‚Äîobviously‚Äîremains. 

My questions to the editors: When is it acceptable to politely disagree with the NYT choices?

Thank you Daniela for fixing my streak!

Among the many disruptions and sleep deprivation of travel, so nice to have the puzzles and the community as a constant.

What fun! Really enjoyed this puzzle. I too was mystified for a while when all those O‚Äôs began to appear, but it soon became clear. Thanks Erik Agard, and thanks Sam Corbin, for your always sparkling commentary. The photos you find to top off your column each time are always a delight.
66-across. chef's kiss. immaculate, no notes. 54-across is really good too
Made me smiiiiiiiiiiiiile!
Fun!

I don't usually love repeating clues, or ones where there can be a million different answers so you need crosses. When this one's theme was dependent on both, and across so much of the puzzle I was a little disappointed.  ...UNTIL I GOT TO 66 ACROSS lol!!!! The phrases were apt with how I felt too. Touch√© Mr. Agard... touch√©. 

I did have to go back and solve a puzzle from the archives to get my puzzling fill for the day lol.

Just a flat out fun puzzle on a coooooooold Tuesday!! 
Thanks for the entertainment, Mr. Agard.
That was so fun! Props, Erik!
loved it. I am always a fan of silly little twists in a crossword
As some others have said, the line of ooos made me laugh. At first I thought I definitely had gotten something wrong, then I filled the whole line in with ooos, then eventually just went... ooohh.
This was a perfect Tuesday puzzle ‚Äî a bit of a theme and a big, meaty laugh. Loved it!
That was really fun! Thanks Erik and Sam. Ooo!
Wow I crushed that.   Quick, with no look-ups!   (rare for me)   This must have been an easy one.   There's no way I got this much better since yesterday.
Meeeeeeeeeeeeh

@Paul
You didn‚Äôt like it? Seriously???

@Sue 

Tbh loving and liking are not the same, are they? Also, are we all supposed to like - or even love - every puzzle? I was born in a place and time that was not big on dissent or difference of opinion and let me tell you - it wasn't very fun.

BTW, as a non-American I am often surprised how eager Americans are to declare their love for a puzzle (which is hyperbole, surely?) while at the same time often expressing being outraged when somebody says they hated a puzzle (not like anybody did that in this thread, but it happens often enough on this board). Apparently not all hyperboles are born equal.

Anyway, I didn't *love* the puzzle either. It was fine in general but the WO...OW did nothing for me. A gimmicky answer. Well, OK. Moving on...

Agree with Paul and Andrzej

My first thought on completion was, "I'm sure 66A is a debut answer, and I hope to never see it again."

@Andrzej 

That was a nice observation, about "loving" and "hating".

I think you've identified an asymmetry towards the positive (assuming love is more positive than hate).

As a consequence, it is better to be an optimist than a pessimist.  I am the latter, and though I know I'd be better off as an optimist, I simply cannot find the ability to change that.  I wish I could.

@Andrzej 

My sentiments exactly. But I had to scroll all the way down from Newest to find another dissenting voice.

@Andrzej 

I love seeing the Polish words you write, and I know it's too much to ask you to give phonetic pronuniciations for them. But is it possible to direct me to a site that would do that? I can pronounce just 2 words: ≈Åomza and ≈Åodz correctly. But I have that whole big police report that I've written about here that I'd love to be able to read correctly, even if I don't understand it. Finally, how *do* you pronounce your name? Thanks!

@Paul 

Skirting the issue of whether or not to love the puzzle in its entirety, where did you get the idea that the whole puzzle was created to accommodate one entry?

@Times Rita For the pronunciation of my name click this link https://pl.forvo.com/word/andrzej/ and scroll down to Lech Andrzej Janerka to polski muzyk. Click the Play icon by that sentence and voila, you'll hear some properly spoken Polish with my name in the mix. (The sound files above that play back with the first letter cut off so they are useless)

@Andrzej Apparently BBC does not train its presenters to pronounce common foreign words correctly. Your name in English has three syllables: live with it. Spare some pity for Agnieszka in the wilds of Chicago. But that's better than the US, where nobody even tries. Let's tie this gratuitous digression together with ‚ñ¨ https://www.reddit.com/r/dankmemes/comments/oe32gx/the_power_of_name_grzegorz_brz%C4%99czyszczykiewicz/ ‚ñ¨ and drop the subject.

@Steve L 

Kayos... Are KOs really spelled like that, and often, too? The horror...

@Andrzej 

It‚Äôs kind of old-fashioned, but so is boxing in general. You do see KOS more than kayos these days, when you s we then at all.
@Steve L your comment is the first time I‚Äôve ever seen KO written as ‚Äúkayo‚Äù. Granted, I‚Äôm not a boxing fan, but I‚Äôm also no spring chicken. I hope no one writes ‚Äútea kayo‚Äù for TKO.

@Steve L 

Your typing is always much more tidy than mine - I often miss typos even though I proof-read my posts...

@Tom 
That is the point... no one says it... so it really IS seriously!
@Tom Owen Wilson, for one! :)
@Tom Yes. They absolutely do. I heard it in my head in my sister's voice after I completed it. It's the only way the clue "Seriously?!" works.

@Janis @Katya @Beth: Okay, if you say so. But . . . I used a stopwatch app to see how long you'd have to draw out "wow" to match the 15 letters in the answer. @James Curran 

Many Native American powwows have ceremonial dances and other traditional practices.

@James Curran Head dancer's what it sounds like.  Public powwow festivities generally revolve around music and dancing, with spectators often encouraged to join in.  There's usually a pair of experienced dancers‚Äîa man and a woman‚Äîto lead.  If you get lost because you don't know the song and can't find the beat, watch the head dancers.

@Derrick 
You have a point, but SKIT is what fit in the puzzle, not sketch. Perhaps you can suggest a different way of clueing SKIT?

@Derrick 

This has been discussed previously, and you are correct that SKIT is now used almost exclusively as a synonym for "sketch" by the vast majority of the population.  The meaning of SKIT as anything other than a brief sketch has more or less gone the way of the buffalo.  Sketches were referred to as SKITS when I was a kid over 60 years ago, and still are.   In fact, dictionaries overwhelmingly define SKIT as, among other things, a comedic sketch.

So that ship has definitely sailed.  If SKIT ever meant something else, no amount of wishing is going to bring things back.

If you are in show business, this may be a case of TCS (Too Close Syndrome).  This is when professional usage of a term is different from common usage, and that professional knowledge clouds one's ability to accept the common usage of the word.

If you're not in show business, then you're just beating a dead horse.

The impact on thousands of human lives in the guise of saving money has already happened, with no clue of what is going to be done with the cash (except maybe millions in unemployment payments)‚Äîcertainly not better salaries for teachers or health research‚Äîdepartments are to be eliminated, and slashes have already been made to all research, including cancer, and this is only the beginning. 

The checks and balances guaranteed in our constitution and our laws are ignored. We are now ruled by a couple of businessmen. One is adding more billions in government contracts and the other has real estate development plans for foreign countries.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

Astro was the dog in the 60s Hanna-Barbera cartoon The Jetsons, a family living in the future. He was a Great Dane who "spoke," but replaced most initial consonants with R.  

Later, Hanna-Barbera produced the cartoon Scooby-Doo, about four teenagers and a dog who solved supernatural mysteries, starring a Great Dane who also "spoke," and also replaced most initial consonants with R.

Since the same studio produced both shows, there was no fear of lawsuit over intellectual property.

Now you know more than you wanted about 60s Saturday morning kids' television.
@Steve L Those shows aired well into the ‚Äô70s as I grew up watching them.

@Steve L the clue is fine, but so is the feedback. As a non-OCD expert, I appreciated the comment.

@Steve according to Mayo Clinic:
Antidepressants approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat OCD include:

Fluoxetine (Prozac) for adults and children 7 years and older.
Fluvoxamine (Luvox) for adults and children 8 years and older.
Paroxetine (Paxil) for adults only.
Sertraline (Zoloft) for adults and children 6 years and older.
Clomipramine (Anafranil) for adults and children 10 years and older.

@Bob T. 
As a physician, I too was a bit interested in the labeling of these two SSRI‚Äôs, but having come across what you discovered, I opted to stop wasting more thought on the issue. The fact is that prescribing practices change fairly rapidly over time and differ between regions, and have little if anything to do with the FDA. Perhaps where the OP lives/works he is describing an obvious fact. However, the bottom line is that this is most certainly, as Steve L coined it, a case of TCS. Who doesn't say "rail trail?" Perhaps people who don't ride bicycles and don't know anyone who does.

SRSLY!

@Mean Old Lady - Here in CT, at least, we have many ‚Äúrails to trails‚Äù pathways. Great for walking and/or biking without the hassle of motorized traffic. It‚Äôs been wonderful to watch these defunct rail lines transformed into nature paths. In New York City there is the delightful urban rail trail - The High Line - an elevated walkway created from an abandoned freight rail, now seeded with native plantings and providing a sweet escape from the scary streets. Rail trails are the best!

@MOL Re: Church Rock, @dutchiris provided a link* in a post much earlier: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/45cj60 *I recall you don't look favorably on Wikipedia; I recommend you go to the link regardless. Very eye-opening! Not least because you'll understand why you (and the rest of us) have never heard of it... (Fwiw, Wikipedia entries all provide source references; I often use it as a jumping off point directing me to deeper research on a given subject.)

@Mean Old Lady If you're ever on Cape Cod... https://capecodbikeguide.com/railtrail.asp There used to be a train that took passengers and goods out to the Cape, back before everybody had cars. When they built Route 6, they ripped out the tracks, and now there's a 25 mile paved trail for bikes.
@Mean Old Lady We just call them "greenways" around here. They mainly follow the sewer lines, so I think it's a bit of a euphemism!

@Grant My great-grandfather was a newspaperman on the Cape. Family lore has it he would meet the train in Hyannis every day to pass on his stories to the Boston papers, and get city news in return. The railroad bridge over the canal is something to experience! https://historicbridges.org/bridges/browser/?bridgebrowser=massachusetts/buzzardsbayrailroadbridge https://www.capetrain.com/rides/cape-cod-canal-excursion/

Grant,

The railroad still went as far as the dunes just outside Provincetown when I was first on the Cape in 1959, decades after Route 6 was built.

@G 
You make a good point about Wiki that I think bears repeating, even though it may be already obvious to most people. I find using the references supplied in the Wiki articles are a fast way to access historically relevant sources and it‚Äôs a lot faster than just googling the topic.
